unnormalised: My love affair with Maths started unexpectedly, during a rather dull summer vacation in Patna. My Nana, a retired professor, decided to take it upon himself to "sharpen my mind," as he put it. Initially, I dreaded the sessions, visions of boring equations dancing in my head. Little did I know, Nana was about to introduce me to the enchanting world of Geometry and Trigonometry.
normalised: My love affair with Maths started unexpectedly, during a rather dull summer vacation in Patna. My Nana, a retired professor, decided to take it upon himself to "sharpen my mind," as he put it. Initially, I dreaded the sessions, visions of boring equations dancing in my head. Little did I know, Nana was about to introduce me to the enchanting world of Geometry and Trigonometry.

unnormalised: Our first lesson was on triangles. Nana, with his characteristic twinkle in his eye, started by drawing a triangle ABC on a large sheet of paper. He explained that the sum of the angles was always 180 degrees. To illustrate, he cleverly used a samosa (that quintessential Indian snack!), cutting it into triangular pieces and demonstrating how they fit together to form a straight line. I instantly grasped the concept, forever associating the angle sum property with a delicious samosa.
normalised: Our first lesson was on triangles. Nana, with his characteristic twinkle in his eye, started by drawing a triangle A-B-C on a large sheet of paper. He explained that the sum of the angles was always one hundred and eighty degrees. To illustrate, he cleverly used a samosa (that quintessential Indian snack!), cutting it into triangular pieces and demonstrating how they fit together to form a straight line. I instantly grasped the concept, forever associating the angle sum property with a delicious samosa.

unnormalised: Next came Pythagoras theorem, a.k.a. the 'magic formula' Nana called it. He told me stories about ancient mathematicians, linking geometry to real-world problems, like calculating the length of a kite string without climbing the tree, or figuring out the height of Qutub Minar from a distance, if one had the measurements needed.

unnormalised: Trigonometry, with its sines, cosines, and tangents, seemed daunting at first. I clearly recall him saying something like "sin(90°) equals 1", which I found strange at the time. But Nana patiently explained it using a simple, hand-drawn unit circle. He connected trigonometry to the movement of planets, the arc of a cricket ball, and the design of bridges. He showed me how trigonometry was used by surveyors to map the Himalayas, and by architects to design the Taj Mahal, explaining the importance of a 30-60-90 degree angle in architecture.
normalised: Trigonometry, with its sines, cosines, and tangents, seemed daunting at first. I clearly recall him saying something like "sine of ninety degrees equals one", which I found strange at the time. But Nana patiently explained it using a simple, hand-drawn unit circle. He connected trigonometry to the movement of planets, the arc of a cricket ball, and the design of bridges. He showed me how trigonometry was used by surveyors to map the Himalayas, and by architects to design the Taj Mahal, explaining the importance of a thirty-sixty-ninety degree angle in architecture.

unnormalised: One particular day, Nana challenged me with a problem: “If a ladder 5m long leans against a wall forming an angle of 60° with the ground, find the distance of the foot of the ladder from the wall.” My initial reaction was panic, but Nana gently guided me, reminding me of the trigonometric ratios we had learned. After a bit of scribbling, I proudly arrived at the answer – 2.5m!
normalised: One particular day, Nana challenged me with a problem: “If a ladder five meter long leans against a wall forming an angle of sixty degrees with the ground, find the distance of the foot of the ladder from the wall.” My initial reaction was panic, but Nana gently guided me, reminding me of the trigonometric ratios we had learned. After a bit of scribbling, I proudly arrived at the answer – two point five meter!

unnormalised: Nana never forced me to memorize formulas. Instead, he encouraged me to understand the underlying principles and derive the equations myself. He would often say, "Maths is not about memorization; it's about understanding the 'why' behind the 'what'." He also emphasized the importance of practice, assigning me problems from the NCERT textbook, like solving 20 problems on coordinate geometry in 1 day.

He also emphasized the importance of practice, assigning me problems from the N-C-E-R-T textbook, like solving twenty problems on coordinate geometry in one day.

unnormalised: He used real-world examples to make the concepts relatable. For example, while teaching about circles, he would point to the wheels of a bullock cart and explain the relationship between the radius, diameter, and circumference. He related calculating the area of a triangle to the size of agricultural fields in Bihar.

unnormalised: Nana also introduced me to famous Indian mathematicians like Aryabhata and Brahmagupta, sharing fascinating anecdotes about their contributions to the field. He told me how Aryabhata calculated the value of pi to 4 decimal places, showing me that mathematics was deeply rooted in Indian history and culture.

unnormalised: That summer with Nana transformed my perception of Maths. What was once a subject of dread became an adventure, a puzzle to be solved, a language to be learned. Geometry and Trigonometry were no longer abstract concepts confined to textbooks; they were tools for understanding the world around me.

unnormalised: Today, as an engineer, I constantly use the principles of geometry and trigonometry in my work. Looking back, I am immensely grateful to my Nana for opening my eyes to the beauty and power of Maths. His lessons, infused with Indian culture and everyday examples, instilled in me a lifelong appreciation for the subject. And whenever I see a samosa, I can't help but smile and remember the summer when Maths became my passion, all thanks to a retired professor and his unconventional teaching methods. Now, whenever faced with complex problems, I often ask myself: “What would Nana do?”, knowing the answer usually lies within those fundamental principles he so passionately shared.
